In the previous case, where A = [0.75] and B = [0.25], we have a high-pass filter with a relatively strong feedback component. This means that the filter will tend to smooth out rapid changes in the input signal, while also attenuating high-frequency components of the signal. The result will be a smoothed version of the input signal, with some attenuation of the signal peaks, as we discussed earlier.

In contrast, when we set A = 0 and B = ones(10,1)/10, we have a very different filter. Here, the feedforward component of the filter is a moving average, which applies equal weights to the current and previous 9 input values. The feedback component of the filter is completely eliminated, as A = 0. This means that the filter will tend to smooth out rapid changes in the input signal, but without any attenuation of the signal peaks.

The result of this filter will be a much more heavily smoothed version of the input signal, compared to the previous filter with A = [0.75] and B = [0.25]. The output signal will be much more gradual, with less pronounced peaks and valleys, due to the averaging effect of the filter. The moving average filter will also tend to eliminate high-frequency components of the input signal, leading to a much smoother output signal overall.

So, in summary, the difference between the two filters will be quite significant. The previous filter with A = [0.75] and B = [0.25] will produce a relatively smoothed version of the input signal, with some attenuation of the signal peaks. The filter with A = 0 and B = ones(10,1)/10, on the other hand, will produce a heavily smoothed version of the input signal, with no attenuation of the signal peaks. The choice of filter will depend on the specific application and the desired characteristics of the output signal.
